prior_works.title: Deeper Insights into Graph Convolutional Networks for Semi-Supervised Learning
prior_works.authors: Qimai Li, Zhichao Han, Xiao-Ming Wu
prior_works.role: Foundational analysis of oversmoothing as Laplacian smoothing
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By showing that standard GCN aggregation performs Laplacian smoothing that homogenizes node features, this work motivates the paper’s core idea to prevent heterophily-induced mixing by keeping category-semantics separated during message passing.

prior_works.title: Graph Neural Networks Exponentially Lose Expressive Power for Node Classification
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Their proof that expressivity collapses with depth directly motivates designing a propagation mechanism—here, multi-track routing—that preserves discriminative information across layers rather than mixing it away.

prior_works.title: On the Bottleneck of Graph Neural Networks and its Practical Implications
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By framing long-range message compression as a bottleneck (oversquashing), this work informs the paper’s strategy to increase effective message capacity via parallel semantic tracks, improving long-distance information flow.

prior_works.title: Representation Learning on Graphs with Jumping Knowledge Networks
prior_works.authors: Keyulu Xu, Weihua Hu, Jure Leskovec, Stefanie Jegelka
prior_works.role: Architecture to mitigate oversmoothing via layer-wise preservation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: JK-Net’s preservation and selective aggregation of multi-layer signals underpins the intuition that separating and maintaining distinct information paths combats feature homogenization, echoed by multi-track propagation.

prior_works.title: Predict then Propagate: Graph Neural Networks meet Personalized PageRank (APPNP)
prior_works.authors: Johannes Klicpera, Aleksandar Bojchevski, Stephan Günnemann
prior_works.role: Decoupling feature transformation from long-range propagation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: APPNP demonstrates that carefully structured propagation (PPR) can transmit information far while limiting smoothing; the proposed multi-track scheme similarly structures propagation to preserve semantics during long-range message passing.

prior_works.title: Geom-GCN: Geometric Graph Convolutional Networks
prior_works.authors: Hongbin Pei, Bingzhe Wei, Kevin C.-C. Chang, Yifan Lei, Bo Yang
prior_works.role: Handling heterophily by decoupling aggregation from raw adjacency
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By showing that respecting structural/positional semantics improves learning under heterophily, Geom-GCN directly inspires the paper’s idea to route messages by category semantics to avoid heterophilic mixing.

prior_works.title: Modeling Relational Data with Graph Convolutional Networks (R-GCN)
prior_works.authors: Michael Schlichtkrull, Thomas N. Kipf, Peter Bloem, Rianne van den Berg, Ivan Titov, Max Welling
prior_works.role: Multi-channel message passing across relation types
prior_works.relationship_sentence: R-GCN’s separation of messages by relation type provides a clear architectural precedent for the paper’s multi-track design, which generalizes the notion of relation-specific channels to learned category-semantics channels to prevent harmful mixing.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—multi-track message passing that separates and independently propagates messages by category semantics—sits at the intersection of two problem lines: oversmoothing and oversquashing. Foundational analyses of oversmoothing (Li et al., Oono & Suzuki) established that standard aggregation mechanisms perform Laplacian smoothing and lose expressive power with depth, directly motivating an architecture that preserves discriminative information rather than mixing it away. In parallel, the oversquashing literature (Alon & Yahav) framed long-range dependency failures as a message bottleneck problem, suggesting the need to increase effective capacity for parallel information streams; the proposed multi-track channels operationalize this by carrying distinct semantic flows.
Architecturally, prior designs that preserve multi-path information flow influenced the approach. JK-Net showed that retaining and selectively combining layer-wise signals mitigates homogenization, while APPNP demonstrated that decoupling transformation from carefully controlled propagation enables long-range information transmission without excessive smoothing. For heterophily specifically, Geom-GCN highlighted the benefit of respecting structural or semantic distinctions rather than naively mixing neighbors, guiding the paper’s decision to route by category semantics to prevent heterophilic mixing. Finally, R-GCN provided a direct precedent for multi-channel message passing by relation type; the present work generalizes that principle from fixed edge relations to learned category-semantic tracks. Together, these strands converge into a design that both enhances long-distance information flow and preserves separation conditions, addressing oversmoothing and oversquashing through semantics-aware, parallel message routing.
